d:desc.d:p: This element encloses the entire corpus and is the common ancestor of all other elements.
XPath: /*

This element contains metadata about a TEI file. Where used in corpus.xml, it contains data referenced by @xml:id from across the rest of the corpus. It includes names and other details of scribes and abbreviations, for example.

When a direct child of teiHeader, fileDesc contains bibliographical information about the file itself. It is also used within msItem/biblFull to contain a keyword list relating to the individual text; this latter structure is mostly unnecessary for the purposes of the corpus but is required for TEI conformance.
This contains the most basic bibliographical information about the work to which it relates, namely, the title and optionally details of anyone responsible.

Where its parent is teiHeader/fileDesc, it provides details for the entire TEI file. When that file is corpus.xml, it contains the corpus title and a list of those who have worked on the corpus in various capacities. Where that file is a transcription file, it provides a title for the transcription and names the editor primarily responsible for that transcription, although it is likely that it has been reviewed by multiple team members in reality.
Where its parent is biblFull/fileDesc (i.e. it relates to an individual text), it provides the title for that text.
This is used in a variety of contexts to contain the title of a file, bibliographical work, or a transcribed text within the corpus or a subsection thereof.

Even where the title element appears within a transcription (e.g. TEI/text/body/div/head/title), it remains part of the editorial apparatus. In other words, the title element is never used to mark up titles that appear in manuscripts. For avoidance of doubt, the title element is also never used for a person's title.

d:list.d:item: @type is also only used in the context of a bibliography entry, where it distinguishes a condensed version of a work's title from the full version.

d:desc.d:p: The respStmt element contains other elements detailing one or more individuals' responsibility for a file or bibliographical work.
The name element is used in a variety of contexts to contain an anthroponym, toponym, demonym, or other sort of name.
Where it appears within respStmt, it contains the name of an individual responsible for a file or bibliographical work. In this context, the name is split into forename and surname.

Where it appears within a transcription (text//name), it is used to mark up the occurrence of a name in a transcription. In this context, it must contain at least one w element and could contain any of the markup used for transcribed text (e.g. unclear, space). If part or all of the name requires emendation, the choice element must be contained within name and not contain it. name can also contain a nested name element, where one name contains another name (e.g. Mael Coluim).
The following attributes are in active use with name:

d:list.d:item: @id: all name elements require this attribute to be compliant with the DASG schema.
@type: when the name element is used to mark up a name in a transcription, this identifies what sort of name it is (e.g. personal, place).

@corresp: when the name element is used to mark up a placename in a transcription, this attribute can be used to link to an entry for that name in an external placenames database (e.g. logainm.ie) via an URL. It can be used whether or not the word(s) in the name have also been linked to headwords and the same URL can be used here and for a contained word's @lemmaRef.

d:desc.d:p: Other attributes (@full, @instant) are at the time of writing (July 2021) assumed by the schema but are not actively used in the mark-up.
resp is used within respStmt to describe a responsibility belonging to the person named in the sibling name element.

When used in the fileDesc element relating to a TEI file, this element contains information relating to the publication of the file and its contents, such as who is responsbile for it and any restrictions on its use.

When used in the fileDesc element relating to a text item from a transcription (msItem/biblFull/fileDesc/publicationStmt), this element simply contains the statement that the item is a "Draft transcription"; publication is already provided by the publicationStmt at file level.
authority refers to the body responsible for the file and its publication.

In corpus.xml, this element contains the contact details for the Faclair na Gàidhlig project and is identified with the @xml:id "authority". Elsewhere, this element links to these details via @sameAs="authority".
This contains contact details for the Faclair na Gàidhlig project, comprised of a series addrLine elements.
This contains a line of the street address for the Faclair na Gàidhlig project.
This contains an email address for the Faclair na Gàidhlig project.
The meaning of this element varies depending on context.
When it appears within addrLine, it contains a telephone number for the Faclair na Gàidhlig project.

When it appears within a transcription, it is used to mark up a number that cannot be tagged as a single word and link to a dictionary headword or where the number appears in a manuscript as apparatus rather than in a syntactic context.
This contains information on how the file can be used. This is set to "restricted" via status and contains the following (within p): "For internal use by the Faclair na Gàidhlig/DASG projects."
The attribute @default is at the time of writing (July 2021) assumed by the schema but is not actively used in the mark-up.
p is a very widely used element. It is used to contain text belonging in a single paragraph.
In corpus.xml and in the teiHeader of transcription files and the hwData file, it is used to organise prose metadata added by editors.

Within transcriptions (text//p), it is used to contain transcribed prose. A new p element is begun when the text switches back from verse to prose, when the scribe visually indicates a major new subdivision of a prose text, or if the editors feel a new paragraph is needed for ease of reading.
The attribute @part is at the time of writing (July 2021) assumed by the schema but is not actively used in the mark-up.
When used in corpus.xml (/teiCorpus/teiHeader/fileDesc/sourceDesc), sourceDesc contains the project bibliography.

When used in a transcription file header (/TEI/teiHeader/fileDesc/sourceDesc), sourceDesc contains details on the texts transcribed from the manuscript in question (msContents) and a physical description of the manuscript (physDesc).
This element contains a bibliography. The type of works detailed in the bibliography is indicated via @type.
The attribute @default is at the time of writing (July 2021) assumed by the schema but is not actively used in the mark-up.

This element contains details about a particular manuscript. It can be used to list a manuscript within the corpus bibliography in corpus.xml or in the transcription file header to describe the manuscript from which transcription has been made.
The attribute @status is at the time of writing (July 2021) assumed by the schema but is not actively used in the mark-up.

This element contains identifying details about a manuscript. When used in the corpus bibliography in corpus.xml, the manuscript is assigned a unique ID via @xml:id. When used in transcription file headers, this ID is referenced via @sameAs.
Used within msIdentifier, this contains the location of the manuscript repository.
Used within msIdentifier, this contains the name of the manuscript repository.
Used within msIdentifier, this contains the manuscript's shelfmark.
This element is also used in some bibliography items (e.g. /teiCorpus/teiHeader/fileDesc/sourceDesc/listBibl/biblStruct/monogr/idno).
How idno is being used is identified by @type.
This optional element within msIdentifier can be used to provide a name commonly in use for the manuscript being identified (e.g. 'The Yellow Book of Lecan' for Dublin, TCD H.2.16 (1318)).

This provides information on a manuscript's history. When used within the corpus bibliography, it simply contains the manuscript's approximate date (history/origin/date). When used within a transcription file header, it contains narrative metadata describing the manuscript's history (history/summary/p).
This is used within the corpus bibliography to provide the manuscript's approximate date (history/origin/date).

When used in corpus.xml or in a transcription file header, this element provides a date for a manuscript(history/origin/date), bibliographical work (listBibl/biblStruct/monogr/imprint/date), or scribe (profileDesc/handNotes/handNote). For bibliographical works, this is a calendar year. For manuscripts and scribes, it is a century or pair of centuries.

When used within a transcription, this element is used to mark up a date, but only when this date is in a format that cannot be analysed and marked up as words. For example, "1411" would be marked up with date, whereas "annaladh an tigerna ann so .i. mile bliadain cetra cead acus seacht bliadna acus tri .xx." ("the year of the Lord today, 1467") would be marked up as normal transcribed text.
In terms of the use of date to provide a date for a scribe, this can require particularly complex use of attributes:

d:list.d:item: @from and @to indicate a precise span of years in which the scribe is known to have been active, where this information is available. If there is only evidence for them being active in a single year, then both attributes point to that year.
@cert provides an editorial certainty level for the dating information contained in the rest of the element.

d:desc.d:p: At the time of writing (July 2021), the dating information for scribal hands is in some disrepair and could use thorough checking in terms of data and standardisation in terms of encoding.
Where date is used to provide the date of a manuscript, the century in which the manuscript was mainly created is indicated via @from-custom.
All date elements require an @id attribute to be compliant with the DASG schema.

Appearing within the corpus bibliograhy, this element contains an individual bibliography item that is not a manuscript. In other words, it is the equivalent of msDesc for monographs, journal articles, book chapters, etc.

Appearing within the corpus bibliograhy, this contains details for either a monograph or the "top-level" component of a publication (e.g. the journal, in the context of a journal article). The "bottom-level" component is detailed under analytic.
In the corpus bibliography, this element is a child of name and contains the author or editor's first name.
This element also appears as a direct child of handNote, containing the scribe's first name, where known.
The attribute @full is at the time of writing (July 2021) assumed by the schema but is not actively used in the mark-up.
In the corpus bibliography, this element is a child of name and contains the author or editor's surname.
This element also appears as a direct child of handNote, containing the scribe's surname, where known.
The attribute @full is at the time of writing (July 2021) assumed by the schema but is not actively used in the mark-up.
This contains child elements providing information relating specifically to the publication of a bibliography item.
This identifies the bibliograhy item's place of publication.
This identifies the bibliograhy item's publisher.
This identifies the series of which a bibliograhy item is part, where applicable.

This element details the "bottom-level" component of a bibliography item (e.g. the article, as distinct from the journal, in an entry on a journal article); it is used alongside monogr, which details the "top-level" component.
This element is used in a variety of contexts.

Within teiHeader, note contains text providing a free prose account of the aspect or datum indicated by an ancestor element. For example, note within handNote provides background information and a description of a particular scribe. In this context, depending on where note is used, p is sometimes required and sometimes not.

Within transcriptions, note is used to insert a footnote. In these cases, it is identfied as such by @type and the editor responsible for the footnote is identified by @resp. In this context, the footnote must be contained within a p child element.
The attribute @anchored is at the time of writing (July 2021) assumed by the schema but is not actively used in the mark-up.
This element identifies which edition of a bibliography item was used.
This contains a number of child elements detailing differnt aspects of how the source material is encoded in the file.
This element is only used in teiHeader in corpus.xml. It provides a brief overview of the FnaG MSS project.
The attribute @default is at the time of writing (July 2021) assumed by the schema but is not actively used in the mark-up.
This element is only used in teiHeader in corpus.xml. It provides an explanation of how material was selected for transcription.
The attribute @default is at the time of writing (July 2021) assumed by the schema but is not actively used in the mark-up.
This element is only used in teiHeader in corpus.xml. It contains a number of child elements detailing different editorial aspects of the project's transcription process.
The attribute @default is at the time of writing (July 2021) assumed by the schema but is not actively used in the mark-up.
This element is only used in teiHeader in corpus.xml. It details the approach taken to emendations of source material on the project.
The attribute @default is at the time of writing (July 2021) assumed by the schema but is not actively used in the mark-up.
This element is only used in teiHeader in corpus.xml. It details the approach taken to normalisation of spelling in source material on the project.
The attributes @default and @method is at the time of writing (July 2021) assumed by the schema but is not actively used in the mark-up.
This element is only used in teiHeader in corpus.xml. It details the approach taken to punctuation in source material and transcriptions on the project.
The attribute @default is at the time of writing (July 2021) assumed by the schema but is not actively used in the mark-up.
This element is only used in teiHeader in corpus.xml. It details the approach taken to sub-dividing source material, from manuscript to word level, on the project.
The attribute @default is at the time of writing (July 2021) assumed by the schema but is not actively used in the mark-up.

d:list.d:item: "italics"
"bold"
"sup" (superscript)

d:desc.d:p: Note that this tag will not necessarily result in the output being formatted this way, as matching handling for hi will need to have been implemented in the appropriate stylesheet.
This provides a series of child elements detailing systems of IDs and attribute values in use across the corpus and definitions thereof.
At the time of writing (July 2021), many of these are incomplete or require review.
Within classDecl, this element contains child elements that detail a particular category of IDs and attribute or element values in use in the corpus. The category is identified via @xml:id.
Note that this element does not have anything to do with editorial or scribal glossing of texts. The latter is marked up within transcriptions using add.
This element is only used in teiHeader in corpus.xml. It contains child elements detailing each abbreviation and ligature (glyph) used in the corpus.
This element contains details on a single abbreviation or ligature, as identified and classified by the project transcribers when encountered in the manuscript material.
This is the name of the abbreviation or ligature, as determined by the project transcribers.
In the teiHeader of corpus.xml, this element contains details of each of the scribes whose hands appear in the corpus

In the teiHeader of each transcription file, this element contains details on the linguistic profile(s) of the text(s) transcribed, a list of scribal hands present in the portion(s) of the manuscript from which transcription was made, and a list of keywords describing the transcription as a whole.
When it appears in msItem, this element is there to contain a list of keywords describing the individual text.
This element contains a set of handNote elements.
In the teiHeader of corpus.xml, these in turn contain details on the scribes.
In the teiHeader of a transcription file, these handNote elements are empty and merely point to the handNote elements in copus.xml via the latter's unique IDs.
This element contains child elements providing information about a scribe.
In the teiHeader of corpus.xml, it contains details on the scribe, who is assigned a unique ID (prefixed "Hand") via @xml:id.
This element appears within a handNote element in corpus.xml and details a region in which the scribe was known to be active. Multiple region elements can be identified if need be.

This identifies the social network to which the scribe belongs. A specific set of element values must be used, they must be spelt correctly, and only one affiliation element can be added to each handNote. A list of these values can be found at taxonomy xml:id="social_group" in corpus.xml. These strict rules are in place because this data determines the colour-coding of Gephi graphs and the program that generates these graphs is expecting particular text strings.
Appearing at the end of each teiHeader, this contains a changelog of changes made to the file.

At the time of writing (July, 2021), the schema assumes that this element has the attribute @status with the value "draft". Also, transcribers have not hitherto kept these changelogs up to date, due to the frequency of changes made while preparing the corpus, sometimes to multiple files. These changelogs are therefore likely to be out-of-date and possibly inaccurate. Their continued presence should be reviewed.
This element describes a change made to the file. It has the following attributes:

d:list.d:item: @when: the date of the change (yyy-mm-dd).
@who: the ID of the editor responsible.

d:desc.d:p: At the time of writing (July, 2021), the schema assumes that this element has the attribute @status with the value "draft".
This is the highest-level element and ultimate common ancestor of a transcription file. The transcription is assigned a unique ID via @xml:id
This indicates how many words are in the transcription ("{count(//w[not(ancestor::w)])} words").
This provides a short summary that introduces the manuscript, briefly surveys the contents, and explains why it has been included in the FnaG MSS Corpus.
This contains one or more msItem elements, each of which details a text included in the transcription.

This introduces the texts transcribed from the manuscript, providing an overall summary of date, genre, subject-matter, authorship, and so forth, as well the reasons for transcribing them and an evaluation of what they contribute to the corpus.
This contains a series of child elements providing details on a single text transcription from the manuscript. The text is assigned a unique ID via @xml:id.
Information specific to this text can be provided via a note child node.
This specifies the location of the text in the manuscript, usually in terms of start and end page/folio, column, and line.
Each of these elements identifies an author or scribe responsible for the text.
The @role attribute identifies whether the individual in question is an "author" or a "scribe"; @corresp has as its value the individual's unique ID.

There is currently no system for formally documenting authors. This is perhaps because relatively few texts in the corpus have a confirmed author; almost all texts that do are likely to be poetry. For this reason, there are currently no author elements where @type has the value "author" and there are no unique IDs specified for authors.
This contains the first few words of the text, as transcribed. If the text appears to be acephalous, this should be indicated with [...] and the first transcribed words added thereafter.
This contains the last few words of the text, as transcribed. If the ending appears to be missing, this should be indicated with [...] and the last transcribed words added thereafter.
This element can be used to provide details on other versions of the text and this version's relationship thereto.

This element identifies the main language used in the text, via @mainLang. If there are other languages that have a significant influence, these can be detailed in a whitespace-separated list as the value of @otherLangs.

Within msItem, this element is only used to ultimately contain a keyword list for the text; the only TEI-compliant way to add such a list at text-level is to create a bibliography item for it via this element.
At the time of writing (July, 2021), the schema assumes that this element has the attributes @status and @default.
textClass, in msItem, contains a keyword list relating to the text.
At the time of writing (July, 2021), the schema assumes that this element has the attribute @default.

d:descs.d:desc: keywords in msItem contains a set of keywords relating to the text.
term in msItem contains a keyword that has been used to help classify the text.

d:desc.d:p: This element appears in editorial commentary (header material and footnotes). It is used to mark up a reference to another source and provide, where possible, an ID for that source (@target). The type of source is indicated via @type.

There is currently (July 2021) no output for material from the corpus that makes use of data from the ref tag or its attributes and it is not used consistently. It should be decided whether it can be used, for example, to automatically generate content for popin windows that would provide bibliographical details or whether the tag should be retired and all referencing done via the in-text author-date references only.
This element contains a description of physical aspects of the manuscript from which transcription has been made. This is done in general via direct child p nodes and objectDesc and handDesc.
objectDesc provides details specifically about the physical state and appearance of the mauscript page.
supportDesc provides details specifically about the physical state of the mauscript page.
support contains a brief formal description of the typical writing surface in the manuscript.
foliation indicates whether the foliation is modern, scribal, or post-scribal, or if multiple systems are in use.

d:descs.d:desc: condition describes the overall condition of the manuscript.
layout provides a brief description of the typical layout of the manuscript page.

d:desc.d:p: This element provides more detailed information on the language(s) used in the material transcribed from the manuscript to which the file relates.
At the time of writing (July, 2021), the schema assumes that this element has the attribute @default.
This element represents a text within the corpus represented teiCorpus; it contains all transcribed material in the file.
This element contains all transcribed material in the file.

Where div has no ancestor div, it represents a text within a transcription, although some transcriptions consist of a single text. It is linked to the details about the text in msItem via @corresp using the text's unique ID.

Where div has an ancestor div, it represents a subdivision of a text. This is used when the text is prose but consists of clearly identifiable units (e.g. a collection of medical aphorisms). This subdivision is assigned a unique ID via @xml:id.
In both cases, the text/subdivision are described with the followign information via attributes:

This element is placed wherever a new scribe begins writing, whether this is at the beginning of the transcription, where they take over mid-text, or where they make an addition to the text. At least one handShift element must appear at the start of the transcription but, if the scribe does not change thereafter, it is not necessary to add any more. The new scribe is indicated via @new using their unique ID.
This element indicates the start of transcription from a new page.
It uses the following elements:

d:list.d:item: @xml:id: This is a unique ID for the new page.

d:desc.d:p: This element indicates the start of transcription from a new line.
It uses the following elements:

d:list.d:item: @n: This is the number of the new line; it need not be a unique ID but it will appear to designate the new line in some outputs.
@xml:id: This is a unique ID for the new line.

d:desc.d:p: w can be used to mark up a transcribed word within a transcription. In the case of compound words, it is used to mark up both the "lower-level" individual component words and the "upper-level" containing word. Alternatively, in hwData.xml, it appears within entryFree providing lexical data on a headword from the corpus.
When used to mark up a transcribed word (whether "lower-level" or "upper-level"), it can have the following attributes:

d:list.d:item: @lemmaRef: this provides a URL for the dictionary entry for the headword (where available) in a recognised dictionary (in order of preference, eDIL, Dwelly via Faclair Beag, Teanglann, placename databases). Where the URL is from Dwelly via Faclair Beag, hwData.xml should be checked to see if the headword is already present and the URL from hwData used instead of the new URL that Faclair Beag will offer.
@lemmaSL: when the transcribed word is the subject of an HDSG slip, this attribute provides the HDSG version of the headword from the slip.
@slipRef: when the transcribed word is the subject of an HDSG slip, this attribute provides the URL for the HDSG slip in the DASG database.
@pos: this details the word's part of speech.

@corresp: When a transcribed word is not found in any recognised dictionary, is documented in an HDSG slip, but not in an HDSG slip that relates to the particular transcribed word in question, the URL for the slip in the DASG database is referenced via @corresp.

@lemmaDW: If the Scottish Gaelic headword to which an eDIL headword is linked in hwData.xml is not the correct Scottish Gaelic headword to which to link the transcribed word, the transcribed word can be linked to a Dwelly headword via this attribute.

@lemmaRefDW: If the Scottish Gaelic headword to which an eDIL headword is linked in hwData.xml is not the correct Scottish Gaelic headword to which to link the transcribed word, the transcribed word can be linked to an URL for the correct Dwelly headword via this attribute. hwData.xml should be checked to see if the Dwelly headword is already present and the URL from hwData used instead of the new URL that Faclair Beag will offer.
@lemmaTG: Where an Irish headword from Teanglann is also of relevance, this can be referenced via this attribute.
@lemmaRefTG: Where an Irish headword from Teanglann is also of relevance, its URL can be provided via this attribute.

@function: In T10, words have been linked via @function to an XML file which provides different readings for these words in previous transcriptions. This is not handled in any output from the corpus and it should be reviewed whether this attribute is still needed.

d:desc.d:p: None of these attributes except @id (see below) is compulsory and should not be included unless the information can be securely associated with the transcribed word.
When used to provide information on a headword in hwData.xml, it can have the following attributes:

d:list.d:item: @type: Uses of the w element in hwData are distinguished from w elsewhere via @type="data".
@lemma: This provides the first instance of the headword linked to the @lemmaRef encountered in the corpus.
@lemmaRef: This is the unique ID for the headword entry in hwData.
@pos: This provides the @pos value from the first instance of the headword linked to the @lemmaRef encountered in the corpus.
@lemmaDW: If the headword is from eDIL, the equivalent headword from Dwelly can be provided here.
@lemmaDW: If the headword is from eDIL, the equivalent headword from Dwelly can be identified via its Faclair Beag URL using this attribute.

d:desc.d:p: In all circumstances, w requires a unique @id in order to be compliant with the DASG schema.

This is used to enclose all transcribed characters involved in an abbreviation or ligature. The direct text children of this element are characters that have been written plene; the characters in the g element(s) are the expansion of one or more abbreviations placed on those characters. Alternatively, the abbreviation could be freestanding, meaning there is only one or more gelements; all ligatures are freestanding.

@cert identifies the certainty with which the transcriber has expanded the abbreviation. @cert="unknown" is used when the transcription is not being made from the manuscript itself but from another modern transcription, where text has been formatted as an abbreviation expansion but no information has been provided on the abbreviation; it means that the transcriber is aware that an abbreviation is used here but cannot comment on the certainty of its expansion as they have no direct access to it.

When the abbreviation has been placed on one word but the expansion belongs in the preceding or following word, or where the expanion straddles a word boundary, g elements are placed where needed to place letters in the words to which they belong. They are then all linked to each other and their parent abbr using a unique ID via @corresp.

An abbr element can be nested within another abbr element, for example, if there is one abbreviation whose expansion is confinsed to the word on which it is placed and one whose expansion straddles a word boundary placed on the same letter. Nested abbr elements can also be used to distinguish two expansions with significantly different certainty levels.
This element contains characters expanded from an abbreviation or ligature. The abbreviation or ligature is identified via its unique ID using @ref.

When the abbreviation has been placed on one word but the expansion belongs in the preceding or following word, or where the expanion straddles a word boundary, g elements are placed where needed to place letters in the words to which they belong. They are then all linked to each other and their parent abbr using a unique ID via @corresp.
In all circumstances, g requires a unique @id in order to be compliant with the DASG schema.
This element represents a space left by the scribe between words within a manuscript line.
Its attribute, @type, can have one of several values:

d:list.d:item: @scribal: this means that the space is an ordinary space for this scribe.
@em: this means that the space is approximately three times as large as a standard space for this scribe.

@editorial: this is used when the text is not being transcribed from a manuscript but from another modern transcription where word division has been standardised; it means that the transcriber does not know whether the scribe is responsible for this space, but the space is there in their source.

d:desc.d:p: This element contains scribal punctuation.
In all circumstances, pc requires a unique @id in order to be compliant with the DASG schema.
This element contains a later scribal addition to the main text, whether by the main scribe of the text or another hand.
It can have the following attributes:

d:list.d:item: @type: this determines whether the addition is an "insertion" or a "gloss".

@hand: this identifies the hand responsible for the addition via its unique ID. Note that, if a different scribe is making the addition compared to that writing the main text, handShift should still be used within add alongside @hand. Note also that the resumption of the first hand should be indicated via handShift after add.
@place: This identifies the location on the page where the insertion has been written (e.g. "above" [the line], "below" [the line], "margin, top").

d:desc.d:p: Note that this element should not be used to make an editorial addition to the transcription; that is done via supplied.
This element marks up text deleted by a scribe, either by the scribe that wrote it or by another.
Note that this element should not be used to make an editorial deletion from the transcription; that is done via choice.
The scribe responsible for the deletion is identified, where possible, via @hand using their unique ID.
At the time of writing (July, 2021), the schema assumes that this element has the attributes @status and @instant.

A transcriber can use supplied to add characters or words to a transcription, if it is thought that these have been omitted purely in error or if their absence risks causing serious confusion. The member of the project team responsible is identified via @resp using their unique ID.
At the time of writing (July, 2021), the schema assumes that this element has the attribute @instant.

seg has various purposes within a transcription. How it is being used is determined by @type. The most common values, which are handled on Meanma, are "cfe" (ceann fo eite), "fragment" (characters from a word that is partly obliterated and cannot be reconstructed), and "catchword". "title" and "margNote" (with @xml:id) are in use but not currently handled on Meanma; their use should be reviewed.
Where @type="fragment", seg requires a unique @id in order to be compliant with the DASG schema.
This element is used to mark up text that the transcriber judges to be unclear.
Why the text is being marked up is indicated via @reason:

d:list.d:item: "text_obscure": the writing is difficult to make out due to erosion, smudging, or unconventional ductus.

"damage": the writing surface is completely gone, with no chance of the original text being recovered; the transcriber has been able to postulate what was written there, however. This is thus editorially equivalent to supplied. The difference is that supplied contains material that was possibly never present in the text but is thought to be needed anyway, whereas unclear reason="damage" postulates a reading for a span of text that probably was once physically present.
"fold": the writing is obscured by the way the page is arranged in the digital image, in a way that is unlikely to be a problem if the manuscript were to be examined in person.
"interp_obscure": the writing is perfectly legible but the words cannot be tagged with confidence.

d:desc.d:p: At the time of writing (July, 2021), the schema assumes that this element has the attribute @instant.

This element contains the metrical lines that make up a stanza, whether determined by metrical analysis or scribal layout. It should always be the direct child of div, whether the stanzas constitute an indepdent verse text in the manuscript or are embedded within a prose text.
The following attributes are used:

d:list.d:item: @n: This is the stanza number; it is not a unique ID but it will be displayed in most outputs.
@type: This should always be set to "stanza".
@xml:id: This is a unique ID for the stanza.

@sameAs: At the time of writing (July, 2021), in one instance, this is used to link a couplet placed elsewhere in the poem to the stanza to which it is thought to belong. This usage should be reviwed, as it is the only example and it may not be handled in any outputs.

d:desc.d:p: At the time of writing (July, 2021), the schema assumes that this element has the attributes @org, @sample, and @part.
This element represents a metrical line within a stanza (lg).
The following attributes are used:

d:list.d:item: @n: This is the line letter; it is not a unique ID but it will be displayed in most outputs.
@xml:id: This is a unique ID for the metrical line.

@sameAs: At the time of writing (July, 2021), in one instance, this is used to link a couplet placed elsewhere in the poem to the stanza to which it is thought to belong. This usage should be reviwed, as it is the only example and it may not be handled in any outputs.

d:desc.d:p: At the time of writing (July, 2021), the schema assumes that this element has the attribute @part.
This element contains an emendation made to the text by one of the FnaG MSS project transcribers.
Appearing within an emendation (choice), this element contains the original reading from the manuscript.
Appearing within an emendation (choice), this element contains the transcriber's amended reading. If the emendation is to delete the manuscript reading, then corr should be left empty.
The transcriber is identified using their unique ID via @resp.
At the time of writing (July, 2021), the schema assumes that this element has the attribute @instant.

This element is used to mark up one or more transcribed characters that cannot be assigned to a marked up word, date, or number. This is usually because the rest of the word is unclear but it can also be because a scribe simply added a single character without meaning it to be grouped with anything else.

c and seg type="fragment" play essentially the same editorial role. seg type="fragment" was introduced because the TEI Guidelines do not permit the use of abbr within c and some "fragments" in the transcriptions contain expandable abbreviations. Going forwards, it could well be possible to mark up all fragments as seg type="fragment" and use c only to mark up intentionally solitary characters.
In all circumstances, c requires a unique @id in order to be compliant with the DASG schema.
gap indicates that material from the text once appeared, or should appear, at this point but cannot be transcribed. It is always empty as, by definition, there is nothing to transcribe.
The reason for the gap, which often resembles that for unclear, is indicated via reason e.g.:

d:list.d:item: "text_obscure": the writing is illegible due to erosion, smudging, or unconventional ductus.
"damage": the writing surface is completely gone, with no chance of the original text being recovered and the transcriber has not been able to postulate what was written there.
"fold": the writing is obscured by the way the page is arranged in the digital image, in a way that is unlikely to be a problem if the manuscript were to be examined in person.
"text_omitted": there is no physical problem with the manuscript but analysis of the syntax or sense or comparison with other versions of the text implies that material has been omitted.
"loss_of_folios": the text is missing its beginning or end or contains a chasm due to the loss of one or more entire folios from the manuscript.

d:desc.d:p: Various other reasons are in use in addition to the above at the time of writing (July, 2021). Not all of the reasons currently in use are handled on Meanma, which can lead to no information being returned for a gap. The reasons in use in this context should be reviewed and streamlined and proper handling developed for what remains.
What other attributes are used depend on what is known about the gap.
If an estimate can be made of how long the gap is, the following are included:

d:list.d:item: @unit: the unit of measurement being used to estimate the gap (e.g. "chars", "words", "folios".

d:desc.d:p: If the length of the gap is unknown (common where @reason="text_omitted"), this is indicated by instead using @extent with the value "unknown".
At the time of writing (July, 2021), the schema assumes that this element has the attribute @instant.
This element indicates the start of transcription from a new column.
It uses the following elements:

d:list.d:item: @n: This is the letter of the new column; it need not be a unique ID but it will appear to designate the new column in some outputs.
@xml:id: This is a unique ID for the new column.

@sameAs: Where the new column begins in the middle of a word that requires editorial emendation, the cb element must be provided twice; as it cannot be given two @xml:id attributes with the same value, as there can only be one @xml:id with a given value in a document, @sameAs must be used in any other instances of the cb.

d:desc.d:p: This element contains a title (title) for a transcribed text or subdivision thereof. At the time of writing (July, 2021), however, it is used inconsistently, sometimes containing a purely editorial title and sometimes containing a title that is part of the transcribed text. This should be reviewed and standardised; alternatively, the two usages should be distinguished via an attribute.

This element is currently (July, 2021) used only once, where a folio of one manuscript in the corpus (MS9) is physically part of another manuscript (MS7). This folio comprises part of a larger text, the rest of which is still present in MS9 (MS9.7). The contents of the folio have been transcribed as a text within Transcription 7 (MS7.7) and an anchor placed at its location within the larger text in MS9. It is linked to the larger text via the @copyOf and @source attributes and its role is identified via @type ("crossRef").
This element is used in hwData.xml to present lists of headwords either added or removed from the corpus since hwData.xml was last generated.
This element is used within list in hwData.xml to present a headword either added or removed from the corpus since hwData.xml was last generated.
This element represents an entry in the hwData.xml database. It contains a record for a single headword from the corpus.
It has the following attributes:

d:list.d:item: @corresp has as its value the URL for the headword (its unique identifier).
@n has as its value the number of times this headword occurs in the corpus.

@source: is added to new entryFree elements when they are added to the database, with the value set to "new". Once the transcriber adding the headword data has finished with the entry, this attribute is removed. It can be retained if the entry needs further attention and will be retained automatically if present when the database is re-generated.

d:desc.d:p: At the time of writing (July, 2021), the schema assumes that this element has the attributes @type and @opt.

This element appears within w in hwData.xml. It is used to present both the headword itself (or the different versions thereof, if headwords have been postulated based on the URL) and forms of the headword(s) that occurs in the corpus.
It uses two attributes:

d:list.d:item: @type: this determines if it is a headword ("lem") or a "form".
@n: this presents the number of times this headword or form appears in the corpus.

d:desc.d:p: This element appears within w in hwData.xml. It indicates the gender of the headword ("m", "f", or "n"), where applicable, as given in whichever recognised dictionaries are being drawn on for this headword.

The linguistic period during which this is the headword's gender is indicated via @xml:lang using XML language codes. If the gender changes between periods, multiple gen elements are used. If a word can have different genders within the same linguistic period, these are distinguished from each other and linked to their accompanying stem (iType) using @n. If the gender remains the same from a given linguistic period onwards, it is the current convention to not list subsequent periods unless the stem changes.
At the time of writing (July, 2021), the schema assumes that this element has the attribute @opt.
This element appears within w in hwData.xml. It indicates the declensional stem of the headword, where applicable, as given in eDIL.

The linguistic period during which this is the headword's stem is indicated via @xml:lang using XML language codes. If the stem changes between periods, multiple iType elements are used. If a word can have different declensions within the same linguistic period, these are distinguished from each other and linked to their accompanying gender (gen) using @n. If the declensional stem remains the same from a given linguistic period onwards, it is the current convention to not list subsequent periods unless the gender changes.
At the time of writing (July, 2021), the schema assumes that this element has the attribute @opt.

This element is used in a hwData.xml entry when the word be used in different parts-of-speech and have different genders and declensional stems depending on how it is used. The POS is identified via @type. Currently, this is only needed for nouns and adjectives.
At the time of writing (July, 2021), the schema assumes that this element has the attribute @opt.
